title: Cash and Working Capital
headline: Accredited by the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants, this course explains transactions via visualisation.
description: This course continues from our basic accounting modules and will help you to explore cash flow and working capital with business simulation models. You will learn about the operating cycle, how to manage cash flow effectively, and how to understand the connection between profit, assets, liabilities and cash flow.
courseDescription:
‘Cash and Working Capital’ has been created by Accounting Intuition and accredited by the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants (CIMA). The best way to learn is through genuine understanding and experience, which is why this course uses a set of ground-breaking visualisation models that explain accounting transactions and balances using the analogy of water pipes and tanks. This simple but effective method lets you develop an intuitive understanding of how to manage cash flow and the accounting operating cycle. The models are used by leading universities to help their students understand financial concepts, and are built into this free online course.

By the end, you will understand cash flow, working capital, current assets and liabilities. You will also learn how profit and loss, assets and liabilities, and cash flow are all linked. This course follows directly on from Basic Accounting (https://alison.com/course/basic-accounting), which introduces all the building blocks of accounting, such as assets, liabilities, equity, debits and credits, financial statements and the fundamental accounting equation.

Even if you are familiar with some of these concepts, you will find it helpful to take that course as a precursor to this one to develop an intuitive understanding using our business simulation models. Whether you are completely new to finance, have never quite felt comfortable with how accounting works or simply want an engaging refresher, take this course to develop an intuitive understanding of basic accounting concepts.

  • Current Assets

  • To see how costs are split up, we are going to explore the working capital cycle. Working Capital is defined in terms of Current Assets and Current Liabilities.
  • Current Assets are cash as well as other assets that are expected to be converted to cash within a year. They are generated continuously by the business.
  • Current Liabilities are liabilities that are expected to be settled in cash within a year.

  • Retail

  • In order to explore working capital and liquidity in any depth it is necessary to look at how it works within an example industry. We are going to consider the example of a retail business, since the business model is fairly simple and everyone is aware of the industry by virtue of being a consumer. The concepts we will introduce though are valid for every industry.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • A traditional retail business buys inventory or stock from its suppliers, stores the products in its warehouses and on its shelves before consumers purchase the items. Let's look at how these accounting transactions work and explore the working capital cycle for a retail business.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Costs are split into direct costs and indirect costs. There are no hard and fast rules, so always check how the company has categorised them
    • Working Capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities
    • Current Assets are cash and any assets that are expected to be converted into cash in the next 12 months
    • Current Liabilities are any liabilities that are expected to be settled in the next 12 months
    • Positive working capital is generally a good sign because it indicates that the business should have enough cash to continue operating. However, to be sure of this the business will need to prepare a detailed cashflow forecast
    • Paying dividends to shareholders is how a company distributes the profit it has earned
    • The Current Ratio = Current Assets / Current Liabilities is another useful measure of a company's liquidity
    • An excessive current ratio indicates that the business has too much value tied up in its current assets and may be struggling to convert them into cash
  • That's it for this lesson. The next lesson on the operating cycle will extend the concepts covered in this lesson.
